position.marginalia_text: Refert Gra[e]cum Epigramma, Bacchum aliquando cu[m] Venere concubuisse, ex eoq[ue] coitu Podagram filia[m] genuisse.

marginalia.translation: The Greek epigram states that Bacchus sometimes slept with Venus, and from that intercourse their daughter Podagra was born.

position.marginalia_text: Therapeutica: pra[e]sertim podagra[e]. An hoc remedio caruerunt Baconus, custos magni Sigilli: et Cecilius, Anglia[e] thesaurarius? duo prudentiss[im]i

marginalia.translation: Therapeutic, especially for podagra. Can it be that Nicolas Bacon, Keeper of the Great Seal, and William Cecil, the English treasurer, are without this remedy? Two most prudent and delightful men.

position.marginalia_text: Alacres, atq[ue] la[e]ti sermones; solatio pleni, ualdeq[ue] cordiales.

marginalia.translation: Cheerful and happy speeches; full of comfort, and greatly affectionate.

marginalia.translation:
Some remedies for gout. Gout is a defect of the joints in the feet; just as arthritis in the hands. Derived from 'foot' and 'hand', and the fierceness of pain which is called 'agria' in Greek (and feras in Latin). From which we say a 'fierce foot' and a 'fierce hand,' and those who suffer from 'a fierce pain in foot and hand,' since this disease inflicts the greatest pain. But very rarely does it affect either castrated men or boys before sexual intercourse with women, or women who have stopped menstruation. Ovid.
Medicine does not know how to resolve the problem of gout.
1. But certain people, when they cleansed themselves by drinking donkey's milk, completely avoided this evil. } Certain people had observed that, by drinking the milk of a donkey, they were freed entirely from gout and arthritis. Niccolo Perotti. The same in another place.
2. Others, when they had refrained from Venus and mead for an entire year, obtained security for their whole life, as the Archbishop of Sipontinus [= Niccolo Perotti] says.
3. Marcus Agrippa, gravely afflicted by this disease in the last years of his life, when he could no longer endure such pain, followed the portentous advice of a certain doctor. The holy emperor, unaware of this procedure, submerged his legs into hot vinegar; and thus he was healed completely.
4. Sextus Pompeius, the leader of Hispania Citerior, while he was watching over granaries that still needed to be winnowed, when seized by the pain of gout, scattered grain above his knees, and he was relieved from the pain in a wonderful way. As a result, afterwards he used this remedy for his exhausted feet.
5. Stinging nettle, named after its burning (because its leaves burns most fiercely when touched) is most useful either cooked with food or preserved. It can be used for a diseased spleen, induration of the stomach, intestinal worms, diseases of the joints, gout, affections of the trachea, cough, fluxes of the bowels, tumors (that is, swellings of the groin), parotis (that is, an abcess near the ear), and chillblains (that is, a disease of the foot which comes from too much cold, affecting especially the heel). The author is the physician Phanias.
Perotti says that it is well known that if anyone washes their feet with a nettle potion during winter, they would not get cold that day. Α certain individual wrote that, if a body is massaged on all of its joints, melancholy would be driven away. Joachim Fortius Ringelberg in 'Experiments'.
In addition, it clears the chest, discharges urine, stops a nosebleed, destroys bladder stones, and braces the uvula. By the same author.
A warm domestic turnip cures inflicted chilblain, and crudely pulped with salt, it is useful for every defect of the feet. Pliny. A maxim which should be carried everywhere.
6. Wagon grease (named after the greased axle of vehicles) rubbed over limbs, cures gout, burns, chilblains; likewise it relieves exhaustion and weariness. It even is useful for chronic coughs or consumption when eaten in pills. Also used for scabies. Perroti.
